Graphical abstract Three methods for repairing spent graphite and an exploration of impurities-catalyzing effect related to spent graphite regeneration are presented. Relative economy, environment, and performance are investigated in detail. Spent battery recycling has received considerable attention because of its economic and environmental potential. A large amount of retired graphite has been produced as the main electrode material, accompanied by a detailed exploration of the repair mechanism. However, they still suffer from unclear repair mechanisms and physicochemical evolution. In this study, spent graphite was repaired employing three methodologies: pickling-sintering, pyrogenic-recovery, and high-temperature sintering. Owing to the catalytic effect of the metal-based impurities and temperature control, the as-obtained samples displayed an ordered transformation, including the interlayer distance, crystalline degree, and grain size. As anodes of lithium ions batteries, the capacity of repaired samples reached up to 310 mA h g−1 above after 300 loops at 1.0 C, similar to that of commercial graphite. Meanwhile, benefitting from the effective assembly of carbon atoms in internal structure of graphite at >1400 °C, their initial coulombic efficiency were >87%. Even at 2.0 C, the capacity of samples remained approximately 244 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles. Detailed electrochemical and kinetic analyses revealed that a low temperature enhanced the isotropy, thereby enhancing the rate properties. Further, economic and environmental analyses revealed that the revenue obtained through suitable pyrogenic-recovering manners was approximately the largest value (5500 $ t−1). Thus, this study is expected to clarify the in-depth effect of different repair methods on the traits of graphite, while offering all-round evaluations of repaired graphite. Keywords Spent graphite regeneration Repair Temperature treatment 1 Introduction Attempts to meet the demand of “low-carbon” goal have resulted in the booming growth of the use of electric vehicle, which has resulted in the inevitable widespread application of lithium ions batteries (LIBs) [1]. The commercial size of LIBs may reach approximately $ 92 billion in 2026, which is twice as much as that in 2020 [2,3]. Further, As the main component of LIBs, the commercial size of sphere-like graphite could reach more than $ 3 billion. However, LIBs have a 5–10 years life-span, that is to say, there is a “wave” of spent batteries scheduled for arrival soon. In contrast to diverse commercial types of cathodes, anode materials with sphere-like graphite have been selected because of their relatively stable physicochemical properties and electrochemical performance [4–6]. Thus, an enormous amount of retired graphite will be produced from spent batteries in the future. Owing to the charge/discharge process in LIBs, certain residual electrolytes and organics are retained on the graphite surface [6,7]. Without suitable treatment, they cause can serious environmental pollution. More importantly, commercial graphite anodes are primarily derived using two methods. One involves artificial synthesis from organic matter, and the other involves natural graphite with a purity of 90%–99.5%. Considering the purity (>98%) of spent graphite, it displays numerous potential values; thus, it is vital to understand methods to recycle spent batteries [8–10]. After mechanical crushing, a series of residual impurities remain even after physical separation (e.g., winnowing and filtration). Assisted by the low-cost flotation process, many impurities can be removed; however, approximately 1% impurity could be still remain [11–13]. As known, the presence of impurities can trigger side reactions, such as the breaking of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) films, destruction of the separator, and capacity fading [14–16]. Moreover, benefitting from previous experience, the introduction of impurities should be emphasized in charge/discharge cycling, where they are mainly derived from the dissolution of the current collector and then inserted into the interlayer architecture [17–19]. Thus, the removal of small impurities” is regarded as the primary issue in the regeneration process. Although certain effective methods for pyrometallurgy and hydrometallurgy have been developed (mainly low-temperature acid leaching, middle-temperature smelting, and high-temperature evaporation), their functional traits, particularly those affecting the material structure, have not been explored in detail. Moreover, other failure mechanisms of graphite have been further explored in terms of structural deterioration, mainly including interlayer collapse, interior defects, and exfoliation of graphite layers, which mainly originate from repeated insertion/extraction behaviors, giving rise to lowered energy-storage ability [20,21]. Nowadays, with improvements in the regeneration temperature, carbon atoms can self-assemble into an integrated lattice structure [22]. Therefore, the repair process is associated with sintering. For example, an ultrafast flash recycling method was used to recover spent graphite through selective Joule heating (∼2850 K), where the heating time was reduced to only a few seconds. The as-resulted samples could display a capacity of 351.0 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C [23]. Moreover, based on the results of Wu et al., the sintering temperature (1673 K, 4 h) was used to treat retried graphite, where the capacity reached up to 360.8 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 1 C [24]. In addition, different types of retired graphite have been explored based on diverse regeneration methods, but without a clear repair mechanism. Therefore, a comparative investigation of the same fading graphite must be conducted. In this study, three regeneration methods were employed for the same fading graphite, and all the regenerated materials exhibited considerable electrochemical properties. However, they still exhibited an interesting evolution of structural traits and electrochemical properties, particularly the coulombic efficiency and structural defects. Thus, an in-depth investigation of kinetic behaviors was conducted, further revealing their effect on the energy-storage ability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of anthracite In this study, the spent soft pack LIBs of Shenzhen Xinmao New Energy Technology Co., Ltd. w ere disassembled. The spent LIBs were placed in a certain proportion of sodium chloride solution for complete discharge. Subsequently, the spent LIBs were manually disassembled and the entire copper foil w as completely obtained in the fume hood. D1-pickling: The 40 cm × 40 cm negative electrode copper foil was separated from the spent LIBs. T he copper foil was submerged directly in water and soak ed for around three cycles until the water turned clear. T he water containing copper foil was agitated gently using tweezers to separate the electrode material. T he stripped graphite was submerged in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent to eliminate the polyvinylidene fluoride ( PVDF ) binder and residual electrolyte , followed by filtering and dry ing the mixture. The 6 g dried sample was transferred to a sand bath at 95 °C and subject ed to purification in a mixed acid solution (H2 SO4:HNO3 =16 mL:5 mL ) for 6 h. This process aids in dissolving metallic impurities. T he purified graphite was rinsed with deionized water until the filtrate reached a neutral pH. Next, the purified graphite was subject ed to gradual heating in an argon atmosphere, increasing the temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1 until it reaches 600 °C, maintaining for 3 h to eliminate residual acid. D2-pyrogenic: The negative electrode copper foil from the lithium iron phosphate battery was cut into small pieces of 1 cm × 1 cm. Subsequently, the copper foil was heated in an argon (Ar) atmosphere, gradually increasing the temperature at a rate of 10 ° C h−1 up to 1400 ° C , maintaining for 2 h. Eventually, the copper foil will melt, transforming into small copper spheres. The graphite and copper particles were separated based on their different sizes using a 600-mesh sieve through water screening. Upon filtration and drying, D2-pyrogenic will be obtained. D3-2800: The electrode material was removed directly from the negative electrode copper foil of the lithium iron phosphate battery by using tweezers. Subsequently, the scraped graphite was carbonized in an argon atmosphere, increasing the temperature at a rate of 10 ° C h−1 until it reaches 2800 ° C, maintaining for 4 h to facilitate complete graphitization. 2.2 Materials characterization To comprehensively examine the characteristics of the samples, we utilized cutting-edge powder X-ray diffractometry (XRD) and Raman spectrometry techniques to analyze their crystal structure and degree of graphitization. Moreover, to evaluate the surface characteristics, we employed the advanced X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) device, Esca Lab Xi+, from the United Kingdom. In addition, we calculated the nitrogen adsorption isotherms using a nitrogen adsorption apparatus to determine the specific surface area (SSA) and pore size of the samples. For a more profound understanding of the particle size distribution, we carried out laser diffraction granulometry. Furthermore, we assessed the functional groups through Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). To gain a complete characterization, we further inspected the morphology, structure, and nanostructure of the samples using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). 2.3 Electrochemical measurement Mixing the active material, conductive carbon black, and sodium carboxymethyl cellulose with deionized water resulted in a uniform mixture (95:2:3), which were stirred for 6 h, and then coated on copper foil by a film coating machine. The coated copper foil was vacuum-dried at 50 °C for 30 min to remove surface moisture, then dried for 6 h at 75 °C. The aluminum foil was then cut into circular pieces with a diameter of 12 mm and a weight of approximately 2 mg using a cutting machine. Polypropylene diaphragm (PP) was used as the separator, and the electrolyte was 1.0 M LiPF6 in vinyl carbonate/ dimethyl carbonate / diethyl carbonate (EC: DMC: DEC = 1:1:1). The charge-discharge process of the cell was tested at various current rates in the voltage range of 0.005–2 V. Autolab-M204 multi-channel electrochemical workstation conducted cyclic voltammetry (CV), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), and galvanostatic charge-discharge tests. The CR2016 Li-ion button half cell was assembled in an argon-filled glove box (H2 O, O2 < 0.1 ppm). Before testing, all coin cells were left for a period of 8 h to allow for proper wetting. 3 Results and discussion In contrast to the complex failure mechanism of the cathode, that of the anode can be mainly divided into surface fading (inactivation of SEI films) and structural destruction (impurity introduction, layer exfoliation, and internal collapse), as shown in Fig. 1 (a). To repair spent graphite, three methods were successfully explored: low-temperature acid washing and sintering, middle-temperature moltening, and high-temperature evaporation. With the strong combining forces of acid-based ions, surficial SEI films can be decomposed, meanwhile Cu elements could be ionized, further inducing the in-depth purification of spent graphite [25,26]. However, owing to the relatively small energy at low temperatures, carbon atoms were barely triggered to form fresh graphitized rings or fill the internal defects [27,28]. In the middle-temperature molten phase, the Cu substances are heated to form a molten liquid phase, further inducing the separation of Cu and graphite, which was mainly ascribed to the flow characteristics of Cu at a specific temperature. In addition, the temperature of the molten Cu points is beneficial for the assembly of atoms [29,30]. For high-temperature evaporation, it is known that, when the sintering temperature increases up to >2800 °C, the metal impurities are effectively evaporated, accompanied with the relatively complete repairing graphite [31]. Herein, three regeneration methods were employed for recycling spent graphite displaying considerable electrochemical properties, along with a detailed analysis of their unique advantages. Relative technologies were used to further explore their detailed repaired structures. The relative XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 1(b), where the characteristic (002), (100), and (004) peaks at 26.5°, 44.5°, and 54.3°, respectively, were indexed to commercial high-purity graphite, indicating that layer-structured graphite was obtained [14,32]. Moreover, no other peaks were detected, indicating high purity. Interestingly, upon amplifying the relatively typical peaks, a slight shift was observed, as shown in Fig. 1(b and c). As known, the (002) peak was closely related with interlayer distance, where Bragg formula (2dsinθ = nλ) was always used to evaluate their layer traits [33]. Herein, n and λ are the constant and wavelength, respectively, and d and θ are the layer distance and angle of crystal planes (always from XRD patterns), respectively. Thus, it could be noted that, the value of d was inversely proportional to that of θ. Interestingly, a noticeable shift was observed towards a higher angle, indicating a decreasing layer distance in the order D3-2800 <D2-pyrogenic <D1-picking. It can be deduced that with an increase in the sintering temperature, the layer distance of graphite can be restored to the normal state (0.334 nm). Moreover, from their calculated values (0.3363 nm for D1-pickling, 0.3360 nm for D2-pyrogenic, and 0.3347 nm for D3-2800), the expansion of the D1-pickling graphite was observed owing to the lithiation/delithiation process; meanwhile, the regenerated D3-2800 exhibited strong structural stability, perhaps bringing about remarkable cycling stability. In addition, the (004) peak was associated with the size of the graphite crystalline grains. According to Debye-Scherrer equation (D = Kλ/(βcosθ)), the relative grain size would be evaluated in sequence of D1-picking <D2-pyrogenic <D3-2800, revealing the increased degree of graphitization, accompanying with the improved conductivity [33]. Fig. 1(e) displays the particle size of the regenerated graphite, where D3-2800 results similar to those of D2-pyrogenic were observed, larger than that of D1-pickling. Meanwhile, a narrow particle distribution was observed for D-2800, which was ascribed to the high temperature, which may induce the aggregation of tiny carbon particles. Thus, it can be concluded that an increased sintering temperature reduced the particle size distribution, which is crucial for the cycling stability of repaired materials. Moreover, the surface properties of graphite materials play an important role in their electrochemical properties; their Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra are shown in Fig. 1(f). Following the sintering process, the peaks located at approximately 1000, 1635, 2923, and 3442 cm−1 indexed to the adsorption peaks of C–O, C=O, –CH2–, and –OH bonds, respectively, were observed. Interestingly, the peak of the C–O bond displayed a blue shift in the order D1-picking <D2-pyrogenic <D3-2800, indicating the weakening of the bond stretching vibration [34,35]. Clearly, an improved sintering temperature increases the relative bond energy. The peak of C=C bonds exhibited a redshift owing to the formation of conjugated structures. It is well known that the specific surface area (SSA) is important for the coulombic efficiency (CE) and energy density. Herein, the SSA was enlarged with the decrease in sintering temperature (D3-2800 (4.2 m2 g−1) < D2-pyrogenic (4.86 m2 g−1) < D1-picking (9.8 m2 g−1)). The similar results revealed that the repaired temperature (>1400 °C) would induce the move of carbon atoms towards defects or vacancy. Through analysis of the pore volume and size, it can be noted that the recovered pristine graphite always displayed rich pores, mainly originating from the erosion of the electrolyte and mineral acid. A large SSA would result in an improved capacity through ion deposition on the surface [36,37]. From an in-depth understanding, active lithium ions may be captured by the internal pores, resulting in poor initial CE (ICE) and CE. By controlling the sintering temperature, a series of regenerated materials were successfully prepared, displaying interesting physicochemical properties, such as decreased interlayer distance and increased crystalline grains, all of which play important roles in their energy-storage capacity. Relative Raman spectra were obtained to further explore the detailed structures. In Fig. 2 (a), the peaks at approximately 1350 or 1650 cm−1 were detected, which was related with D-peaks (defects and vacancies) and G-peaks (graphitic carbon). The crystallinity of graphite can be quantified using the I D/I G value, with larger I D/I G values indicating lower crystallinity. Interestingly, the gradual decrease in the intensity of the D-peaks was in the order of D1-picking >D2-pyrogenic > D3-2800, revealing that an increased temperature enhanced the degree of graphitization. The I D/I G was calculated to be 1.07, 0.53, and 0.19 for D1-picking, D2-pyrogenic, and D3-2800, respectively. Obviously, a relatively high temperature enables the movement of tiny graphitized wafers towards larger grains, facilitating the enhancement of structural stability. Assisted by Gaussian fitting, their peaks could be divided into four peaks (D1, D2, D3, and D4), where D1 and D2 were associated with the edges of the graphene layers and the surface of the graphitic crystals, and D3 and D4 were related to in-plane defects and sp 2-sp 3 hybridization behaviors, respectively. Based on an area comparison of the D3 and D4 samples, a reduction in interlayer defects was found with an increase in temperature. When the temperature increased up to approximately 2800 °C, the peaks related to D3 and D4 nearly disappeared, indicating the complete repairing of internal structure. However, the D1 and D2 peaks were still observed, mainly resulting from edge defects. Certainly, compared to commercial graphite, edge defects may bring about improvements in anisotropy, perhaps deteriorating the rate properties. There were still certain vacancies on the surface of D1-picking, boosting the broadening of the reaction energy distribution, and finally resulting in rapid redox reactions. The relative size of graphite in the D2-pyrogenic sample was larger than that of the other samples, primarily owing to the catalytic effect of the impurities (Cu, etc.) Interestingly, the largest crystalline size was observed for D3-2800, demonstrating the stacked self-assembly of graphitized microcrystals, which facilitated the enhancement of isotropy, accompanied by improved cycling stability. According to Eqs. (1) and (2), the D2-pyrogenic samples exhibited a relatively small anisotropy, perhaps resulting in a fast ion-shutting process. Detailed XPS analyses were performed to further explore the surface traits. In Fig. 2(h–j), the peaks related to the O element were observed, which may be derived from the adsorption of O2 from the atmosphere or relative bonds. Interestingly, supported by the increase in temperature, the O content gradually decreased, mainly owing to the reduction in surficial defects. Fig. 2(e–g) shows the high-resolution O 1s XPS, where the peaks at 291.2, 286.7, 285.2, and 284.8 eV are closely associated with the C(O)–O, C=O, C–OH, and C–C bonds. Among them, the C=O bonds play an important role in the energy storage properties. Certain coupled electrons can be offered, which is beneficial for rapid redox reactions (i.e., pseudocapacitive behavior). Interestingly, in comparison to D1-picking and D3-2800, the C=O content for D2-pyrogenic was larger, where the direct and shortened processes may induce carbonization of the organic matrix from the SEI films or electrolyte. Thus, it can be concluded that an increase in temperature could repair the internal disordered graphitic structure, surficial defects, and vacancies. However, it should be acknowledged that a suitable direct calcination temperature induces the formation of C=O bonds, facilitating the enhancement of electrochemical properties on the graphite surface. (1) L a ( nm ) = ( 2.4 × 10 - 10 ) λ 1 4 ( I D / I G ) - 1 (2) L D 2 ( nm 2 ) = ( 1.8 × 10 - 9 ) λ 1 4 ( I D / I G ) - 1 To further explore the morphology and internal structure of the as-regenerated graphite, SEM and TEM images were obtained, as shown in Fig. 3 . As anticipated, with an increase in the sintering temperature, the smoothness increased in the order D1-picking < D2-pyrogenic < D3-2800, indicating the degree of structural repair. The high temperature induced the assembly of carbon atoms into an integrated crystalline structure, which is beneficial for the decrease in anisotropy, resulting in improved cycling stability. TEM images of the layered structure are shown in Fig. 3(a2–c2). Certain carbon nanotubes and super carbon particles were clearly residual, which were derived from the degrading batteries. Although efficient flotation separation was achieved, certain small carbon materials remained. Commercial anodes are composed of carbon nanotubes and acetylene black, which are prepared at high temperatures and display considerable structural stability. Thus, the tiny residual carbon particles barely induced tailoring of the electrochemical properties of the repaired samples. Interestingly, a microcrack could still be found in D1-pickling, whereas the other samples displayed an integral graphite layer. The other samples exhibited large and integrated graphite layers. For the D2-pyrogenic sample, a large crystalline lattice was observed, mostly owing to the catalytic effect of the Cu atoms. Owing to the enlarged particle size, the ion diffusion paths were successfully prolonged. Moreover, with increasing Li ion content in the interlayer, electrostatic repulsion weakened in-depth ion storage, particularly first-order lithium-ion storage. In Fig. 3(a3–c3), through the comparison of graphite edge, it can be noted that increasing the sintering temperature could result in a decrease in surficial/marginal defects. In the SAED images, an improved degree of crystallinity was observed, revealing that D3-2800 showed a large crystalline volume, which agrees well with the discussions above. Interestingly, for the D2-prrogenic, rich oxygen content was observed, exhibiting the introduction of O-doping, which would be conducive to the enhancement of pseudocapacitive behavior. Herein, it could be deduced that the low temperature barely induced the binding of carbon and O atoms, whereas the high temperature further destroyed the C=O bonds, which coincided well with the results above. Thus, it can be concluded that an improved sintering temperature boosts the repair of spent graphite, including edge and in-plane defects, but with the removal of fascinating oxygen-containing groups. By capturing their fascinating physicochemical evolutions, the relative electrochemical properties were successfully measured, as shown in Fig. 4 , at current densities of 0.001–2.5 V. In Fig. 4(a), the cycling stabilities were carried out at 0.1 and 1 C, where their initial discharge/charge capacities reached 442/361 mA h g−1 for D1-pickling, 408/361 mA h g−1 for D2-pyrogenic, and 404/362 mA h g−1 for D3-2800 at 0.1 C. Owing to the unrepaired defects and tiny closed pores, Li-ions were confined on the surface, resulting in the relative incomplete reversible reaction. In the full cell, the supporting Li ions mainly originate from the cathode; thus, the high ICE of the repaired graphite plays an important role. Through the analysis of ICE, the values (81.2%, 88.4%, and 89.6%) were obtained, thus it could be deduced that the frustrating sites could be repaired with sintering temperature (>1400 °C). In case of over 300 cycles at 1 C, the relative capacity of the as-repaired samples remained approximately 328, 314, and 313 mA h g−1, similar to that of commercial graphite, which presented in Table 1 . Interestingly, at high current densities, an evident activation process was observed. According to previous reports, at high current densities, Li ions with a high moving rate would crash into graphite [38,39]. Considering the insertion mechanism of the graphite sample, the interlayer distance was further expanded, thus increasing the energy-storage capacity. Here, the D1-pickling samples showed a relatively short active process, which was attributed to their relatively large interlayer distances. Interestingly, compared with the active process of D3-2800, that of D2-pyrogenic was longer and slower. With an in-depth understanding of the regeneration procedure, during the molten extraction of metal elements, part of the interlayer architecture was catalyzed, further improving their anisotropy, whereas the evaporation method could induce higher isotropy. When the current density increased up to 2 C, the capacity was approximately 182.4, 197, and 244 mA h g−1, along with the prolonged active platforms. By comparing the cycling curves at different current densities, the length of the active procedure at 2 C was found to be twice that at 1 C. In other words, the degree of expansion of the interlayer distance was determined by the number of inserted Li ions and not by the current densities. Moreover, compared to D1-pickling and D2-pyrogenic, D3-2800 exhibited stronger cycling stabilities accompanied with the considerable rate properties. Notably, after 300 cycles, their ion storage capacities remained similar, mainly originating from the insertion effect of Li ions. Fig. 4(b) shows their 1st electrochemical property at 0.1 C, where the similar curves could be found at 0.08 V above, indicating their same interlayer energy-storage abilities. However, compared with the former, a longer platform of D3-2800 was noted; that is, the enhanced GIC reaction was located at 0.08 V below. Larger graphitized microcrystals offer stronger layer-storage abilities owing to the ordered expansion process. A detailed analysis of the charge/discharge curves is shown in Fig. 4. For the reducing capacity, a gradual decrease in capacity was noted, mainly derived from the activation process. Interestingly, for the increasing part, the energy-storage platforms between 0.005–0.4 V were found simultaneously. After further cycling, the platform at 0.08 V below was effectively enhanced, revealing the in-depth ion-storage behaviors. In addition, for their rate properties, increasing the temperature could enhance the redox reactions. However, when the sintering temperature increased to 1400 °C, their properties remained similar. Thus, it can be concluded that, for repaired graphite, the relative activation process is related to interlayer expansion. To further explore their kinetic behavior, the relative CV curves and fitting results are shown in Fig. 5 . All displayed typical energy-storage peaks of graphite, where the peak at low voltage was mainly derived from the insertion behaviors and SEI formation. Notably, owing to the relatively high SSA of the D1-pickling samples, broadened peaks were observed, mainly due to the formation of thick films. Moreover, at 0.75 V, one weak peak was observed, revealing the existence of adsorption behaviors. Meanwhile, no relative peaks were found for other samples, further demonstrating that the relatively high temperature induces the movement of carbon atoms towards defects and vacancies, further bringing about great repair results. Further, by comparing the peak intensities for different materials from the 1st to 3rd cycles, relatively stable peak intensities were observed for the D2-pyrogenic and D3-2800 samples, indicating considerable reversibility. Further exploration of the CV curves at different scan rates revealed a good linear relationship, confirming the excellent rate properties. However, for the D1-pickling and D3-2800 samples, the linear relationship of D2-pyrogenic remained stable, demonstrating their promising potential at ultra-large current densities, which may be owing to the rich existence of C=O bonds. These bonds offer shared electron pairs, facilitating rapid redox reactions. Thus, with a further increase in the scan rate, D2-pyrogenic may exhibit an effective energy-storage capacity. Moreover, it is known that, the capacity of materials is derived from two parts, including diffusion-determined and surface-controlling behaviors. The contribution of graphite to graphite is mainly determined by the insertion behavior of the lithium ions. Here, the relative equation is displayed, where n is the number of electrons transferred, A is the reacted area (always about the area of the electrode), and D is the concentration of the electrolyte or the Li concentration of the lattice. For 0.3–0.9 mV s−1, a relative relationship was observed for peak current (I p) and the square root of scanning rate (v 1/2). After their fitting, the corresponding values of slope for the oxidation/reduction process were approximately 2.25/1.83 for D1-pickling, 1.88/1.22 for D2-pyrogenic, and 2.73/2.13 for D3-2800. After the calculation, the relative values were 2.78 × 10−10 and 1.83 × 10−10 cm2 s−1, 1.93 × 10−10 and 0.81 × 10−10 cm2 s−1, 4.1 × 10−10, and 2.49 × 10-10 cm2 s−1, respectively. Compared to the two former samples, the D3-2800 samples displayed higher diffusion coefficients, mainly due to their high isotropy. With increasing scan rate, the relative diffusion coefficient was obviously reduced. From an in-depth understanding of the diffusion process, it could be deduced that the increased current densities enable an increase in the diffusion resistance in the interlayer owing to the repulsion of Li ions with the lack of redox time. However, based on the above results, excellent rate properties were obtained. Thus, the pseudocapacitive contributions in Dunn’s report can be evaluated. Profiting from defects and rich functional groups, the former indicates relatively strong pseudocapacitive behavior. However, their energy storage capacity is determined by their diffusion/surface-controlling behaviors. The contribution of the pseudocapacitive behavior is shown in Fig. 5(g). As evident, the increasing contribution improved with increasing scan rate. Thus, it can be concluded that the sintering temperature and impurity-removal mechanism play important roles in the electrochemical properties. Moreover, with an increase in isotropy, their capacities could be further improved. However, owing to the thermal-catalysis effect, enhanced anisotropy was observed, perhaps resulting in inferior ion-diffusion behavior. It should be acknowledged that the capacity of the repaired graphite is mainly determined by slow diffusion and fast capacitive behavior. At low scan rate (0.5 mV s−1), certain area of the pseudo-capacitive exceeded the pristine curves, which was interpreted as the diffusion-controlling behaviors serving an important role for the total capacity. Interestingly, with increasing scan rate, the peaks were blue shifted; that is, the surface-controlling behaviors play dominant roles. At 5.0 mV s−1, their capacity mainly derived from the surface-controlling behaviors. Interestingly, in the low-voltage regions, the capacity was still determined by diffusion-controlling behaviors. From the analysis of the diffusion process, when a large number of lithium ions were deposited on the graphite surface, the electrostatic pressure further induced in-depth insertion, even at high scan rates. Interestingly, for D3-2800, the diffusion-controlled contribution accounted for a significant proportion. From the aspect of isotropy, they exhibited considerably more uniform ion insertion paths, boosting the ion insertion process. Compared to the other samples, D2-pyrogenic displayed smaller ion-insertion contributions owing to its strong anisotropy. Thus, it can be concluded that the residual metal elements induced the evolution of the graphite lattice in certain areas, resulting in the improvement of anisotropy. Meanwhile, benefitting from the acid-assisted impurity removal, a relatively small anisotropy was noted for D1-pickling, whereas the low temperature hardly induced uniform secondary growth of the lattice. However, when supported by high-temperature roasting, the graphitized lattice and flakes were homogenized and exhibited considerable isotropy. To further explore the internal resistance, Nyquist Plots were obtained at different states. In Fig. 7 (a), the relative curves of the as-repaired samples are displayed, which can be divided into two parts: the semicircle at high frequency is associated with the charge transfer resistance (R ct), and the oblique line at low frequency is related to the ion diffusion resistance (W s). Rs is related to the internal resistance of natural electrode materials, separators, and electrolytes. As is evident, similar value of R ct was observed for D1-pickling and D2-pyrogenic, approximately 310 Ω. Whereas, that of D3-2800 was approximately 180 Ω, facilitating the ions/e− shuttling, mainly indicating that the high-temperature would induce the growth of graphitization degree. Owing to the catalytic effect of Cu, the ion diffusion paths were prolonged, resulting in poor ion movement. Moreover, Fig. 7(b) shows the relationship between phase and frequency, where the relative relaxation coefficient at 45° were further calculated to be 3.15 × 10−3 s for D1-pickling, 6.83 × 10−3 s for D2-pickling and 4.65 × 10−4 s for D3-2800. It is well known that a small value reveals fast ion-shuttling for D3-2800, which matches well with the results above. The relative Nyquist plots for the different cycles are shown in Fig. 7. With cycling from the 3rd to 33rd cycle, the diameter of the semicircle at high frequency decreased, mainly owing to the deposition of Li ions, which further improved the conductivity. Meanwhile, from the 33rd to the 100th cycle, the charge-transfer resistance decreased. The expanded graphite interlayer distance was a result of the large number of Li atoms, leading to a smooth insertion/extraction process. Thus, their reduced resistance to Li deposition was recovered, and consequently, their charge-transfer resistance increased. Moreover, for their ion diffusion coefficients, a similar phenomenon was noted, further demonstrating the above points. Compared with the latter two, the activation process was obviously shorter for D1-pickling, mainly ascribed to its large interlayer distance, which agrees well with previous reports [56–58]. Meanwhile, an analysis of the bode-phase angles revealed that the value of θ (80°) for D2-pyrogenic was larger than that of other samples, revealing their strong capacitive behaviors from rich functional groups. Thus, compared to the other samples, the D3-2800 sample exhibited the lowest resistance, accompanied by a considerable ion diffusion rate. Meanwhile, owing to the residual Cu-atoms of the D2-pyrogenic, the large graphite layer was further catalyzed by prolonged diffusion paths. Owing to the charge repulsion of the layers, adequate ion diffusion was barely achieved, resulting in poor ion diffusion behavior. However, when the sintering temperature was exceeded 1400 °C, relatively stable layer structures were successfully formed, always displaying considerable cycling stability. A suitable recovery value has been deemed an important standard for evaluating relative recovery methods. Thus, relative economic and environmental analyses of different graphite recovery methods were conducted, as shown in Fig. 8 . The recycling process is shown in Fig. 8, where the pickling-sintering recycling method displayed a longer procedure than the other methods, which may result in a complex operation process. By comparing the latter recycling process, it can be noted that impurities (such as Cu and Al) were removed before and after the sintering process. In the pyrogenic process, the nanosized particles agglomerated into relatively large particles, which were then successfully removed through screening. For the high-temperature sintering process, the impurities were removed through a two-stage process, wherein the impurities were removed through screening, and the residual impurities were further evaporated at high temperatures, which finally resulted in high energy consumption. Through the detailed economic analysis of stoving and sintering, a similar energy consumption cost (412 $ t−1) was obtained, smaller than that of high-temperature sintering process (760 $ t−1). More significantly, the total cost was further calculated, where the introduction of acid solution increased the cost of the recycling process (for the pickling-sintering process, from 418 $ t−1 to 819 $ t−1). Considering the industry demand, a relatively low cost would capture more attention. Further exploring their relative revenue, pyrogenic recovery methods delivered a high value. Thus, considering their similar electrochemical properties, pyrogenic recovery methods may be regarded as an effective method in industry. The calculation of the energy costs is described below. Generally, the commercial price of graphite is $8000 t−1. However, considering the cost of recycling waste graphite, we have set the price of our regenerated graphite at $6000 t−1. The energy consumption of the entire process primarily included the power consumption of the vacuum furnace, energy consumption of slurry stirring, and energy consumption of the oven. The rated power of the vacuum furnace for processing 1 t of graphite per cycle was 1000 kW. During heating, the energy consumption was 90% of the rated power. Energy consumption during insulation was 40% of the rated power, and no additional power was required for cooling. The rated power of the stirring motor was 11 kW, and the rated powers of the oven and vacuum pump were 12 and 80 kW, respectively. The calculation of the energy costs is described below. The price of electricity was $0.128 (kWh) −1. D1-pickling Energy consumption of the vacuum furnace: 90% × 1000 kW × 2 h + 40% × 1000 kW × 3 h = 3000 kWh Energy consumption of the vacuum pump: 80 kW × 2 h = 160 kWh Energy consumption of slurry stirring: 11 kW × 6 h = 66 kWh Energy consumption of oven: 12 kW × (6 + 8) h = 168 kWh Total energy cost: (3000 + 160 + 66 + 168) kW h × $0.128 (kWh) −1 ≈ $418 Reagent Costs: The price of concentrated sulfuric acid was $22.3 per ton. Given that 6 g of graphite consumes 16 mL of concentrated sulfuric acid and 5 mL of concentrated nitric acid, approximately 2.7 kiloliters of concentrated sulfuric acid is consumed per ton of graphite, which is approximately 2.71.84 tons. The price of concentrated nitric acid is $279 per ton, and approximately 0.84 kiloliters of concentrated sulfuric acid is consumed per ton of graphite, which is approximately 0.841.25 tons. The cost of concentrated sulfuric acid: 2.71.84 t × $22.3 t−1 ≈ $111 The cost of concentrated nitric acid: 0.841.25 t × $279 t−1 ≈ $29 Total cost = Total energy cost + Reagent cost = $418 + $111 + $290=$819 D2-pyrogenic Energy consumption of the vacuum furnace: 90% × 1000 kW × 2.4 h + 40% × 1000 kW × 2 h = 2960 kWh Energy consumption of the vacuum pump: 80 kW × 2 h = 160 kWh Energy consumption of slurry stirring: 11 kW × 6 h = 66 kWh Energy consumption of oven: 12 kW × (6 + 8) h = 168 kWh Total energy cost: (2960 + 160 + 66 + 168) kW h × $0.128 (kWh) −1 ≈ $412 Reagent cost: $0 Total energy cost = Total energy cost + Reagent cost = $412+$0=$412 D3-2800: Energy consumption of the vacuum furnace: 90% × 1000 kW × 4.7 h + 40% × 1000 kW × 4 h = 5830 kWh Energy consumption of slurry stirring: 11 kW × 6 h = 66 kWh Energy consumption of the oven: 12 kW × 6 h = 72 kWh Total energy cost: (5830 + 160 + 66 + 72) kWh × $0.128 (kWh)−1 ≈ $760 Reagent cost: $0 Total cost = Total energy cost + Reagent cost =$760+$0=$760 4 Conclusions Spent graphite was successfully repaired using various recycling methods. Interestingly, owing to the different impurity-removing methods and sintering processes, the as-resulting samples displayed ordered changes in physicochemical properties, such as increased interlayer distance, crystalline grain size, and degree of crystallinity. For their electrochemical properties, the as-resulted samples displayed a capacity of approximately 310 mA h g−1 even after 300 cycles at 1.0 C, similar to that of commercial graphite. At 2.0 C, the capacity of the as-optimized sample reached 244 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles. With the assistance of detailed electrochemical analysis, it could be deduced that high temperatures and existing impurities would induce improvements in anisotropy, further resulting in a decrease in the rate properties. Although acid washing methods can effectively remove residual impurities, the lack of temperature and sintering time results in incomplete repair. Supported by kinetic analysis, it could be deduced that the decreased anisotropy induced fast surface-controlling reactions, leading to considerable rate properties. Detailed economic and environmental analyses further demonstrated the advantages of pyrogenic recovery methods and high-temperature sintering. Given this, this study is expected to shed light on the in-depth understanding of repaired graphite while offering a significant evaluation of various repair methods. coredata.dc:description: Spent battery recycling has received considerable attention because of its economic and environmental potential. A large amount of retired graphite has been produced as the main electrode material, accompanied by a detailed exploration of the repair mechanism. However, they still suffer from unclear repair mechanisms and physicochemical evolution. In this study, spent graphite was repaired employing three methodologies: pickling-sintering, pyrogenic-recovery, and high-temperature sintering. Owing to the catalytic effect of the metal-based impurities and temperature control, the as-obtained samples displayed an ordered transformation, including the interlayer distance, crystalline degree, and grain size. As anodes of lithium ions batteries, the capacity of repaired samples reached up to 310 mA h g−1 above after 300 loops at 1.0 C, similar to that of commercial graphite. Meanwhile, benefitting from the effective assembly of carbon atoms in internal structure of graphite at >1400 °C, their initial coulombic efficiency were >87%. Even at 2.0 C, the capacity of samples remained approximately 244 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles. Detailed electrochemical and kinetic analyses revealed that a low temperature enhanced the isotropy, thereby enhancing the rate properties. Further, economic and environmental analyses revealed that the revenue obtained through suitable pyrogenic-recovering manners was approximately the largest value (5500 $ t−1). Thus, this study is expected to clarify the in-depth effect of different repair methods on the traits of graphite, while offering all-round evaluations of repaired graphite.
